net.java.dev.designgridlayout
Class DesignGridLayout

java.lang.Object
  net.java.dev.designgridlayout.DesignGridLayout
All Implemented Interfaces:
LayoutManager
public class DesignGridLayout
extends Object
implements LayoutManager

Swing LayoutManager that implements "Canonical Grids" as used by graphic artists to design magazines, posters, forms...

Canonical grids are useful for, but not limited to, all kinds of forms mostly used in UI dialogs.

DesignGridLayout provides a convenient API to have automatically well-balanced canonical grids panels. With this API, there is no need for any graphical designer.

Typically, DesignGridLayout will be used as follows: 

 public class MyPanel extends JPanel {
     public MyPanel() {
         DesignGridLayout layout = new DesignGridLayout(this);
         setLayout(layout);
         //...
         layout.row().label(labelA).add(fieldA);
         layout.row().label(labelB).add(fieldB);
         //...
         layout.centerRow().add(okButton, cancelButton);
         }
         //...

Author:
Jason Aaron Osgood, Jean-Francois Poilpret

MARGIN_DEFAULT

public static final int MARGIN_DEFAULT
Use this constant with margins(int, int, int, int) method if you want to keep the calculated margins for one or more of top, left, bottom or right margins values.

See Also:
Constant Field Values
Constructor Detail

DesignGridLayout

public DesignGridLayout(Container parent)
Builds a DesignGridLayout instance attached to a Container. This instance should be then used to add rows and components to the parent container.

In no way should the Container.add(java.awt.Component) and Container.remove(int) ever be used with parent.

Parameters:
parent - the container for which we want to use DesignGridLayout; cannot be null.
Method Detail

margins

public DesignGridLayout margins(int top,
                                int left,
                                int bottom,
                                int right)
Define special margins (in pixels) for the parent container. You normally won't use this method because DesignGridLayout uses the best margin values for the current used Look and Feel. However, it may be useful when you use DesignGridLayout in special containers such as views used in a docking-based application, in which case you would rather avoid wasting too much space as margins for each single docked view.

Parameters:
top - top margin in pixels
left - left margin in pixels
bottom - bottom margin in pixels
right - right margin in pixels
Returns:
this instance of DesignGridLayout, allowing for chained calls to other methods (also known as "fluent API")

leftRow

public INonGridRow leftRow()
Adds a left-aligned row. Left-aligned rows are NOT canonical grids but avoid the otherwise mandatory use of several LayoutManager for one single dialog.

The new row is located under the previously created row, which means that each line of code using this method creates a new row and all lines can be read as defining the visual UI of the container.

Returns:
a new left-aligned row which API is used in a chained-way (fluent API) to add components to the row.

rightRow

public INonGridRow rightRow()
Adds a right-aligned row. Left-aligned rows are NOT canonical grids but avoid the otherwise mandatory use of several LayoutManager for one single dialog.

The new row is located under the previously created row, which means that each line of code using this method creates a new row and all lines can be read as defining the visual UI of the container.

Returns:
a new right-aligned row which API is used in a chained-way (fluent API) to add components to the row.

centerRow

public INonGridRow centerRow()
Adds a center-aligned row. Left-aligned rows are NOT canonical grids but avoid the otherwise mandatory use of several LayoutManager for one single dialog.

The new row is located under the previously created row, which means that each line of code using this method creates a new row and all lines can be read as defining the visual UI of the container.

Returns:
a new center-aligned row which API is used in a chained-way (fluent API) to add components to the row.

row

public IGridRow row()
Adds a grid-aligned row. This row is using a canonical grid for determining size and location of components in the row.

The new row is located under the previously created row, which means that each line of code using this method creates a new row and all lines can be read as defining the visual UI of the container.

Returns:
a new grid-aligned row which API is used in a chained-way (fluent API) to add components to the row.

emptyRow

public void emptyRow(int height)
Adds a new, fixed-height, empty row to the container. This row will never contain any component and is used only for introducing vertical space between rows or groups of rows.

Parameters:
height - the height in pixels of the new created empty row.

addLayoutComponent

public void addLayoutComponent(String constraint,
                               Component component)
Do not add components via the parent container's Container.add(Component) method, use directly DesignGridLayout API instead.

Specified by:
addLayoutComponent in interface LayoutManager

removeLayoutComponent

public void removeLayoutComponent(Component parent)
Do not remove components via the parent container's Container.remove(Component) method; removing components from a DesignGridLayout-managed container is not supported.

Specified by:
removeLayoutComponent in interface LayoutManager
